title: (x) Rotisserie - Holland Title {Stephen}
content:
Can someone please help me work out what this font is? thanks - sye :)

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [Rotisserie.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20081119151619/http:/typophile.com/files/Rotisserie.jpg) | 45.48 KB |

 [‹ help identifying this font](http://web.archive.org/web/20081119151619/http:/typophile.com/node/16406 "Go to previous forum topic") [Sony Nw-a1000 6Go green - bitmap (or b/w hinted) UI font ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081119151619/http:/typophile.com/node/16387 "Go to next forum topic")
author: Simon Robertson

comments.content:
Correcting myself...

It is probably [Holland Title](http://web.archive.org/web/20081119151619/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=catalog.fontdetail&displayfontid=C.107024.0.0&attributes.sampleSize=48&sampleText=Rotisserie&sampleSize=74), slightly condensed with a fat stroke affecting the fill shape, and other small alterations.

Holland Title is a great alternative to Albertus which I’ve neglected until now.

Interesting near-Albertus to consider in the future, Stephen. Thanks.

Designers: (blank), Trademark Info: N/A —\> this seems to be the case far too often with the Fontshop offerings. Do you happen to know where Holland Title came from and (meant as constructive criticism) is anyone working to fill in these Fontshop blanks?

I share your concern. I clench my teeth every time I see a blank credit. Sometimes it’s our fault, but sometimes we’re provided with no info from the foundry. In this case, it’s Monotype Imaging, and [they fully credit Hollis Holland](http://web.archive.org/web/20081119151619/http:/www.fonts.com/findfonts/detail.htm?pid=205066&grab_id=0&page_id=9155&query=holland%20title). I’ll see that it’s fixed on our end.

I’ve always heard the “old timers” at Compugraphic speak highly of [Hollis Holland](http://web.archive.org/web/20081119151619/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Hollis%252BHolland), who was the first design director (Senior Typeface Designer) for the company. He was an accomplished calligrapher and book jacket designer years before he came to CG.

Here’s a snipet from the archives:

_ **1973** - Compugraphic enters into a new technology with introduction of the VideoSetter® I and II. The VideoSetter has an operating speed in excess of 400 lines per minute, making it particularly attractive to the newspaper market for handling classified advertisements and stock market text, as well as body text. This year marks its first release of a typeface exclusively developed by Compugraphic. Named for its creator, Senior Typeface Designer Hollis Holland, Holland Seminar was promoted for high-quality promotional literature._
Thanks Norbert. I know very little about history of the ’graphics (Compu and Scan) so I appreciate all the background you can illuminate.
